PostValue.explanation: The idea is interesting and potentially provocative, but as presented it is speculative and not load-bearing for EA priorities. If CTRH were true it would be revolutionary for cosmology and would change major research and funding choices, but the post does not confront key, well-established constraints (gravitational lensing, CMB anisotropies and structure formation, cluster dynamics/Bullet Cluster, relativistic consistency) and uses ad hoc parametrizations that many alternative fits can match for rotation curves alone. For the EA/rationalist community it’s a low-to-moderate epistemic interest (worth skeptical attention and requests for stronger tests), and for general humanity its practical importance is small unless much stronger empirical and theoretical support is produced.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Internal theoretical inconsistency and missing conservation/accounting of dynamics — You repeatedly present CTRH as a “non-force, structural predisposition” yet in Paper 2 you introduce an explicit coupling term α∇T in the equation of motion (i.e. a force). This contradiction needs to be resolved. Actionable: (a) state whether CTRH is intended to change the effective forces or the geometry/connection; (b) give a single, consistent derivation from a well-defined action (show the matter+T Lagrangian, perform the variation, derive both matter EOM and the field EOM), and (c) show how energy–momentum is conserved and whether/why Lorentz invariance or the equivalence principle is preserved or broken. Without this the hypothesis reads as an ad hoc addition rather than a coherent alternative theory.  

2) Failure to address the key, well-known empirical constraints that any dark-matter alternative must meet — Rotation-curve fits alone are necessary but far from sufficient. You do not engage with gravitational lensing (including strong lensing), CMB/large-scale structure constraints, Bullet-Cluster-like colliding systems, solar-system and binary-pulsar tests, nor with the empirical correlations (e.g. Tully–Fisher or the radial-acceleration relation) that alternatives like MOND aim to reproduce. Actionable: add at least one worked example showing CTRH predictions for (a) lensing by a galaxy or cluster, and (b) how the model scales with baryonic mass (i.e. whether a and b are free per galaxy or predictable). If you can’t match these or at least show plausible ways to match them, be explicit about the limitations and testable predictions (including falsifying observations).  

3) Mathematical formulation and presentation problems that undermine credibility — The field Lagrangian and field equation in the post are written sloppily (formatting errors, undefined notation like m2, T^3 vs λT4 vs λT^4 ambiguity), there is no coupling term in the action (you add α∇T by hand), and your chosen solution T(r)=−β/r is singular and seems chosen to mimic a 1/r^2 force (so you may be reproducing dark-matter-like effects by construction). Actionable: (a) rewrite the field theory cleanly (fully covariant form, units, signs); (b) show the origin of coupling α from the action; (c) analyze the field’s regularity and stability (behavior at r→0 and r→∞, any screening mechanism to satisfy solar-system bounds), and (d) provide model-selection metrics (e.g. number of free parameters, AIC/BIC or cross-validated predictive error) comparing CTRH fits to standard dark-halo and MOND fits so readers can judge whether CTRH is genuinely more parsimonious/predictive rather than just another curve-fitting formula.

Addressing these three items will substantially increase the paper’s credibility and make it much easier for the community to evaluate or falsify CTRH.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback identifies multiple high-impact problems: an internal theory inconsistency (claiming a non-force structural effect but introducing an explicit force term), failure to engage the core empirical tests any dark-matter alternative must pass (lensing, CMB/LSS, Bullet Cluster, solar-system and binary-pulsar limits, Tully–Fisher/RAR), and sloppy/missing mathematical formulation (no consistent action, undefined notation, singular field ansatz, no parameter-counting or model-comparison). These are actionable, central issues that would embarrass the author if left unaddressed and are necessary for the hypothesis to be evaluated credibly.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No recognizable presence under the name 'KaedeHamasaki' in EA/rationalist venues (LessWrong, EA Forum, conferences, major blogs) or in academic/public media up to mid‑2024. Likely a pseudonymous or niche online identity with no notable public profile; if they are active under a different real name, that identity was not identifiable.

PostClarity.explanation: Strengths: The post is well structured (clear sections for motivation, model, tests, and next steps), uses accessible language for a broad EA audience, and gives concrete model forms and empirical claims rather than only handwaving. Weaknesses: Several technical notations are malformed (broken LaTeX/equations), some key claims are underspecified (how fits were done, baseline comparisons, treatment of lensing/GR), and the causal language (‘‘no conventional force’’ vs. adding α∇T) is ambiguous. With cleaned notation, more detail on methods/results, and clearer distinction between structural vs. dynamical claims, the post would be substantially clearer.

PostNovelty.explanation: For readers familiar with EA/rationalist/longtermist circles and with physics, most of the core moves here are familiar: using a scalar field, adding a coupling to baryons, fitting simple analytic rotation‑curve functions, and proposing a non‑particle alternative to dark matter are all well‑trodden paths (compare MOND/modified inertia, scalar/vector field dark‑matter alternatives, and emergent‑gravity proposals like Verlinde). The mathematically stated model (φ^4 Lagrangian, gradient coupling) and the empirical fit form are standard tools. What is somewhat novel is the conceptual framing as a non‑force “directional predisposition” or global “tension” anchored to a cosmological center — that particular metaphysical redescription and emphasis on structural causality (rather than forces or particles) is less common and may catch lay readers as new. However, because it maps closely onto existing alternative gravity/field ideas and raises familiar cosmological issues (e.g., no obvious center, lensing/structure formation challenges), it’s only moderately original to the general public and low in novelty to experts.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post is clear about motivations, presents a concrete phenomenological fit (v(r)=a(1−e^{−r/b})) and a sketch of a field-theoretic underpinning, and is explicit about open questions and falsifiability. Weaknesses: The core causal claim (a non‑force “structural” tension field causing circular orbits) is under‑specified and poorly connected to established physics (no consistent relativistic formulation, energy/momentum accounting, or derivation of the proposed static profiles from the field equations). The empirical case is thin: fits to a few galaxies with an ad‑hoc two‑parameter curve are not convincing absent comparisons to baryons‑only and dark‑matter fits across a large, diverse sample, and important observables (gravitational lensing, CMB, structure formation, Bullet Cluster, Tully–Fisher relations, rotation‑curve diversity) are unaddressed. There are also technical problems (unclear units/couplings, T(r)=−β/r not shown to solve the field equation with the given Lagrangian, 2D simulations and brief RMSE reporting give insufficient evidence). Taken together, the idea is interesting enough to merit further development, but as presented it lacks rigorous reasoning and sufficient empirical support to be considered a viable alternative to dark matter.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Summary judgement: mixed / uncertain. The author’s materials and plotted rotation-curve fits appear to exist (an OSF project with papers and the figure is publicly hosted), which supports the claim that a phenomenological two-parameter formula v(r)=a(1−e^{−r/b}) was fit to galaxy data; the OSF project and the posted figure are evidence of that. ([doi.org](https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/W4EZD), [res.cloudinary.com](https://res.cloudinary.com/cea/image/upload/f_auto%2Cq_auto/v1/mirroredImages/gdGQu3Dn3vZhpgGJ3/xjk0vwbrujdl425urqt0)) Strengths: (1) high-quality rotation-curve data for galaxies like NGC 2403, NGC 3198 and NGC 6946 are public (THINGS / SPARC) and have typical velocity uncertainties of order a few km/s, so a low RMSE claim (≲6 km/s) is not implausible in raw curve-fitting terms. ([iopscience.iop.org](https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0004-6256/136/6/2648?utm_source=openai), [arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.09251?utm_source=openai)) (2) The field Lagrangian given (a standard scalar φ^4-type form) is a familiar mathematical object in field theory, so the formal expression is internally consistent as a toy field model. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartic_interaction?utm_source=openai)) (3) The post correctly notes that direct-detection searches for common WIMP candidates have so far produced null results — e.g., XENONnT and other liquid-xenon experiments place strong exclusion limits. ([journals.aps.org](https://journals.aps.org/prl/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevLett.131.041003?utm_source=openai)) Weaknesses / reasons for caution: (a) Existence of preprints and plots is not the same as independent empirical validation. I found the OSF project and the plot the author provided, but I found no peer‑reviewed publication or independent replications that confirm the RMSE/fit-comparison claims or that the model reproduces other observables (gravitational lensing, galaxy-galaxy dynamics, cosmological large-scale structure). ([doi.org](https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/W4EZD), [res.cloudinary.com](https://res.cloudinary.com/cea/image/upload/f_auto%2Cq_auto/v1/mirroredImages/gdGQu3Dn3vZhpgGJ3/xjk0vwbrujdl425urqt0)) (b) The claim that CTRH matches or outperforms “standard dark matter fits” requires rigorous statistical comparison (same data, same error model, information criteria, cross-validation) and tests across larger samples; I found no such published comparisons. (c) The proposed coupling term (α ∇T) and a specific T(r)∝1/r solution are presented phenomenologically; without a physical genesis that also reproduces lensing and cosmological constraints, a 2-parameter fit to rotation curves alone is insufficient to overturn dark matter or modified-gravity explanations. (d) Established empirical regularities (radial-acceleration relation / MOND-like phenomenology) mean that phenomenological fits must also be shown to preserve those relations across the SPARC sample — I found no evidence the CTRH paper has been tested across that full dataset. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1609.05917?utm_source=openai)) Overall: the post’s empirical claims are partially verifiable at the level of “the author produced fits and a model on OSF” (verified), but the stronger empirical claims (statistically comparable/better than dark-matter fits; viability as a full alternative able to explain lensing and cosmology) are not supported by independent, peer‑reviewed evidence I could find. That leads to a middle score (5) indicating credible preliminary work but insufficient independent validation.
sources: OSF project: 'The Central Tensional Return Hypothesis (CTRH)', Kaede Hamasaki (OSF DOI: 10.17605/OSF.IO/W4EZD).
Author figure: 'Rotation Curve Comparison Across Galaxies (CTR Model Fit)' (image hosted on cloudinary) — image shown on the OSF / post.
SPARC database & SPARC paper: Lelli, McGaugh & Schombert, 'SPARC: Mass Models for 175 Disk Galaxies with Spitzer Photometry and Accurate Rotation Curves' (2016).
THINGS / high-resolution rotation curves (e.g. de Blok et al. / Walter et al., 'High-resolution rotation curves and galaxy mass models from THINGS').
McGaugh, Lelli & Schombert, 'The Radial Acceleration Relation in Rotationally Supported Galaxies' (Phys. Rev. Lett. 2016 / arXiv:1609.05917).
XENONnT collaboration, 'First Dark Matter Search with Nuclear Recoils from the XENONnT Experiment' (Phys. Rev. Lett. 2023) — example of recent direct-detection null results.
Review / reference for scalar φ^4 Lagrangian (quartic scalar field interaction discussion, e.g. 'Quartic interaction / φ^4 theory' reference).
